test.title: Who gets tested?
description: Apparently testing isn't enough for everyone, and medical personel decides who gets tested.
CDC recommends a priority system to setup for who should get tested.
People who have the coronavirus symptoms and who are more likely to get seriously ill because of other health conditions such as diabetes, cancer, Heart, lung, or kidney disease.

test.title: How to be tested?
test.how_to_summary: You call your nearest health facility. And you should be ready to answer the following;

signs.type: Do you have a fever or cough?
Do you have shortness of breath?
data: Can’t get enough air into your lungs
Have to work harder than usual to breathe in or out
Need to breathe in before you’re done breathing out

signs.type: Have you been in close contact (within 6 feet) with someone who has COVID-19?
Has someone with COVID-19 coughed or sneezed on you?
Did a health official tell you that you’ve come into contact with COVID-19?

test.title: Types of Covid-19 Testing
test.test_types: CDC recommends COVID-19 to be tested by a method called nasopharyngeal swab where technical people will put a special 6-inch cotton swab up both sides of your nose and move it around for about 15 seconds. It might be uncomfortableIt but won't hurt. Then send the swab to a lab to test the material from inside your nose.

test.title: Covid-19 tests spot two types of antibodies
data: IgM, which your body makes for about 2 weeks before the levels drop
IgG, which your body makes more slowly (within about 4 weeks) but which usually last longer
test.more: It takes a lab about 24 hours to run a test and a few days for you to get your results.

test.title: Steps to avoid spreading the virus
test.steps_to_summary: Having a positive COVID-19 test means you apparently have or recently had the virus.
data: Stay home, apart from getting medical care.
Isolate yourself from other people at home.
Don’t share dishes, cups, eating utensils, or linens with others.
Cover your coughs and sneezes. Wash your hands often with soap.
Clean and disinfect common surfaces like phones, doorknobs, or counters regularly.
